title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from the Central African Republic engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Central African Republic?
preds: The only choice they have to feel that they exist is the movement of violence. I prefered to think the situation trough a kind of psychoanalitical point of view.
This country is a mess; don’t fell question will be resolved as yes, however
Having been in CAR for work last year, I think some of the armed groups are not unlikely to launch systematic attacks on civilians in the coming year, however, 1,000 killings is a high number.

CAR is still unstable, its weak security forces and a violent political history the risk of an armed group engaged in killing of 1,000 civilians or more cannot totally be ruled out. Although, violent incidents involving armed groups elements and self-defence groups continue to fuel intercommunal tensions and remain the primary source of violence against the population. However, my estimation that an armed group would be responsible for killing from 75 to 125 civilians.
The outside view:
Deterrent factors to be taken into consideration: 
•	Khartoum Peace Agreement signed with 14 armed groups
o	Establishment of Special Mixed Security Units
o	13 Ministers represent the armed groups
•	MINUSCA (11,500 troops and police) 
•	Special and International Criminal Courts
•	AU
•	CAR’s National Security Forces (NSF)
The inside view:
•	In addition to 18 armed groups, there are a number of local militia or auto-defence groups, and regional mercenaries, which, allegedly, are all responsible for crimes committed against the population
•	According to INSO from January to April 2019 total 1597 security incidents recorded in CAR  (source: https://www.ngosafety.org/country/central_african_republic). However, they are related to Crime with multiple perpetrators rather to an armed conflict/campaign launched by an armed group. 
•	Peace Agreement casts doubt since similar agreements in 2014, 2015 and 2017 all broke down.
•	Slow implementation of DDR
•	MINUSCA criticised being ineffective  
•	Special Criminal Court still not operational 
•	Increased Russian footprint in CAR and lack of its operational transparency 
•	Partial lifting of arms embargo by UNSC.
•	NSF still in reformation stage. Needs human resources, training, equipment and motivation.

Acknowledge powderkeg but fact that militia hand over those responsible (which happened) means parties still trying to adhere to peace agreement

Due to the lack of recent information from the Central African Republic it is difficult to determine if there are any cases of systematic killings. Historically speaking, killings of civilians has occurred, but this is predominantly due to fighting between government and non-government forces. This does not undermine the fact that there are cases of human rights abuses occurring in the country, however, such as rape, forced displacement, and violence towards civilians. But as of the recent evidence presented, there is a very unlikely chance of a group that will commit any forms of systematic killings against civilians.

Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007 Other judgments: 
- EWP estimate at 3.7%. [1]
- Crowd forecast here is 3%. Inside view:
- According to EWP, "CAR has an ongoing non-state-led mass killing, perpetrated by anti-balaka groups, which began in 2013." [1] They write further: "In the course of the violent conflict in the Central African Republic (CAR) since 2013, Séléka/ex-Séléka rebels and opposing anti-Balaka armed groups have carried out systematic attacks on Christian and Muslim civilian populations, respectively. While many groups have been involved in violence, it is clearest that anti-Balaka militias were responsible for more than 1,000 civilian fatalities." [2] So EWP count one side of the ongoing civil war [3] as engaging in mass killing. 
- the CFR has a good background on the country's violence [4]
- options for another episode are: (1) (ex-)Seleka rebels or (2) another group entirely
- (2) seems fairly unlikely since most of the violence seems to be aligned. There are some exceptions [3], but they strike me as exceedingly unlikely to escalate. Perhaps 1%, but likely less.
- (1) is hard to tell. There was another attack in October, killing 15 [5], January, with four people killed [6]. The peacekeepers don't seem to help much. [7] According to Wikipedia, casualties seem to be low, but I'm not sure how much I can trust these numbers. While a peace agreement was signed in February, these seem to have been routinely violated in the past. [8] So I wouldn't put much trust into them. Overall, I don't see any signs that violence would escalate this year in particular. Overall judgment:

The key here is "an armed group". There are several main groups and many splinter groups (who ignore ceasefires), but a unified operation seems unlikely. Increased MINUSCA presence (as well as other international oversight) along with the new criminal court are likely to help keep the level of fighting moderate and sporadic.
